Selected Answer: B
The best practice to secure the network in the guest waiting area would be to disable unneeded switch ports in the area. Switch ports are the ports on a network switch that are used to connect devices to the network. By disabling unneeded switchports, you can prevent unauthorized devices from being connected to the network. This is more effective than enabling MAC filtering, which only blocks devices with unknown hardware addresses and may not fully protect the network. Signing NDAs or lowering the radio strength may not effectively secure the network. NDAs do not harden the network, and lowering the radio strength may cause attenuation issues for guests

Selected Answer: B
B. Disable unneeded switchports in the area.

Disabling the unneeded switchports in the area would prevent unauthorized access to the network. This can help ensure that only authorized personnel have access to the network and improve overall network security.

Selected Answer: B
B is the correct answer. Disabling unneeded switchports will disable unused switchports ENTIRELY, making unauthorized switchport connections impossible in the first place.

A is incorrect because it has nothing to do with the question in hand. You are not going to share corporate data with guests in a waiting area, and furthermore, NDAs do not harden the network.

C is incorrect because it is not the best option. Sure, you can limit the range of the WAP antenna's signal to stop outsiders from connecting to the wireless network, but that would cause attenuation issues for guests unless you know what you are doing.

D is incorrect because that is security through obscurity. Anyone with security knowledge can easily spoof MAC addresses nowadays, so whitelisting MAC addresses is not a great idea in a guest waiting room.

questions.question_text:
A network technician receives a support ticket about an employee who has misplaced a company-owned cell phone that contains private company information.
Which of the following actions should the network technician take to prevent data loss?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The root cause of the issue could be a captive portal being active for the WLAN. When a device connects to a WLAN that has a captive portal, the device is typically redirected to a login page in order to gain access to the internet. This is done by the device receiving HTTP redirections when it tries to access the internet. Therefore, verifying if a captive portal is active for the WLAN would be the most likely solution to this issue.

If the question does not say it, don't assume the scenario.

discussion.content: This question isn't making sense to me. In textbooks it is recommended not to connect or allow access of IoT devices to public networks. Captive Portals are best used for public networks and business guest's usage. The only hint here is the HTTP redirect, meaning there is a possible security issue.
When there is https redirect and no internet connection, it is trying to redirect you back to a misconfigured captive portal

Selected Answer: B
B. Verifying if a captive portal is active for the WLAN.

The symptoms of only receiving HTTP redirections when data is requested indicate that a captive portal is active for the WLAN. A captive portal is a web page that requires users to complete some action, such as accepting terms and conditions, before they can access the internet. It is often used in public Wi-Fi hotspots or other situations where there is a need to control or monitor access to the network. The IoT sensor may not be able to complete the required action, leading to the redirections.

questions.question_text: Which of the following topologies requires the MOST connections when designing a network?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Think of Mesh = Mess

Selected Answer: A
A mesh topology requires the most connections when designing a network. In a mesh topology, every device on the network is connected to every other device, creating a network in which there are many paths between devices. This means that in a mesh network with N devices, there will be N(N-1)/2 connections.

comments.content: To add on, mesh topologies are commonly used in WANs/the Internet, so you are literally connecting networks (which have many connections already) to many other networks.

discussion.content: Its a mesh to be right here. :)

Selected Answer: A
A. Mesh topology requires the MOST connections when designing a network as it uses a point-to-point connection between every pair of devices in the network, resulting in a large number of connections.
